It is a mat-forming moss that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. The plant has delicate, wiry stems with closely spaced, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a layer of fine, translucent cells. Escobariopsis laui is characterized by its unique spore-producing structures called capsules, which are typically borne on short, erect stems. This moss is often used in ecological studies to monitor air quality and soil conditions due to its sensitivity to environmental changes.
